Normalizing will ensure\n    #     that each point in x is a weighted sum of all points in Y with those weightings\n    #     totalling 1.0. Therefore, \n\n    Returns\n    -------\n    numpy.ndarray\n        Array that can be multiple by scalar values to smooth them. \n        Smoothing can be done inherently, or from one surface onto another. \n    \n    Notes\n    -----\n    https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/434629/3-d-generalization-of-the-gaussian-point-spread-function\n    ";

 019:     # bool normalize=True
 020: ):
 021:     """
 022:     Get gaussian kernal for every point in array X to every point in array Y.
 023:     If X/Y are the same, then this will just smooth array X. 
 024:     If X/Y are different, can be used to smooth one onto the other. 
 025: 
 026:     Parameters
 027:     ----------
 028:     X : numpy.ndarray
 029:         First array to compute gaussian kernel for
 030:     Y : numpy.ndarray
 031:         Second array to compute gaussian kernel for
 032:     sigma : float, optional
 033:         Standard deviation (sigma) for gaussian kernel, by default 1.
 034:     # normalize: bool, optional
 035:     #     Whether or not to normalize the scalar values. Normalizing will ensure
 036:     #     that each point in x is a weighted sum of all points in Y with those weightings
 037:     #     totalling 1.0. Therefore, 
 038: 
 039:     Returns
 040:     -------
 041:     numpy.ndarray
 042:         Array that can be multiple by scalar values to smooth them. 
 043:         Smoothing can be done inherently, or from one surface onto another. 
 044:     
 045:     Notes
 046:     -----
 047:     https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/434629/3-d-generalization-of-the-gaussian-point-spread-function
 048:     """
 049:     cdef Py_ssize_t x_i_shape, x_j_shape, y_i_shape, y_j_shape
 050:     cdef my_type tmp_total, gaussian_multiplier, two_sigma2
 051:

 085: 
 086:     # The following normalizes all of the values. This ensures that the points in an image won't be darkened with smoothing
 087:     # Otherwise, all of the kernel values will be < 1.0 so the image will get darker.
 088:     # If we had a continuous surface, then the sum of the kernel on each point would be 1.0
 089:     # Since we have a discrete surface, when we calculate the kernal at finite points we lose data between those points
 090:     # Normalizing in this way helps preserve the scale of the data. E.g., the mean of all of the points will be less
 091:     # than the original mean, but it will be much closer than if we did not normalize.  
 092: 
 093:     # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaussian_blur#Implementation
 094: 
 095:

  __pyx_t_8 = __pyx_v_x_i_shape;

    __pyx_v_i = __pyx_t_10;

+097:         for j in range(y_i_shape):
    __pyx_t_11 = __pyx_v_y_i_shape;
    __pyx_t_12 = __pyx_t_11;
    for (__pyx_t_13 = 0; __pyx_t_13 < __pyx_t_12; __pyx_t_13+=1) {
      __pyx_v_j = __pyx_t_13;

+098:             den_view[i] += kernel_view[i, j]
      __pyx_t_20 = __pyx_v_i;
      __pyx_t_19 = __pyx_v_j;
      __pyx_t_18 = __pyx_v_i;
      *((double *) ( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_den_view.data + __pyx_t_18 * __pyx_v_den_view.strides[0]) )) += (*((double *) ( /* dim=1 */ (( /* dim=0 */ (__pyx_v_kernel_view.data + __pyx_t_20 * __pyx_v_kernel_view.strides[0]) ) + __pyx_t_19 * __pyx_v_kernel_view.strides[1]) )));
    }
  }
